segments.text: But in any case, the four areas I was saying, those four, we feel the mechanical engineering profession, obviously this department, addresses three of those in a major way, and that's materials, productivity, and energy.
Water resources is an area that we don't get involved in directly.
We don't feel that's a major research area for ourselves.
The other three we address in a major way.
In the materials area, we feel that's a very critical area for the future.
It's as critical as energy.

We have a large material group that's doing research in very basic characterization of metals, looking at techniques for more energy efficient mechanisms for producing metals, looking at ways to improve metals from both the alloying and surface treatment.
We are looking at ways to improve, for instance,
a utility of cast iron for very low temperatures and very high temperature application, looking at metals as it applies to structures, for instance, gas turbines.
And on the other hand, we're making a large move toward non-metal materials, plastics, composite materials.
It appears quite obvious that the materials of the future are going to be quite different than the materials of the past in the sense of being...
composite type materials.

We have a plastics engineering laboratory that's concentrating on the manufacturing and mechanical properties of high volume plastics, short fiber composites, problems associated with tooling and manufacturing.
We just started a packaging program, just hired a new faculty member in that area.
We feel obviously that packaging in whatever form from
cereal boxes to spacecraft, packaging is a very important part of our society.
It consumes a lot of materials.
It consumes a lot of energies.
We're a very packaging-oriented society as opposed to a more primitive society.
Whether it's McDonald's, hamburgers, or how do you get coal out of Montana, packaging is an essential part of modern society.
So manufacturing and materials area is a rapidly growing area and a very significant area, we think, for the state and obviously the nation.
That touches on some of the research we're doing.
How do you fund this research?
About our total research budget that I mentioned, last year
When you talk about research dollars, you need to specify a little bit.
If I talk about research in place, contracts in place during the last fiscal year, it was about $2.25 million.

If you talk about cash flow, the dollars spent from the first fiscal year to the last fiscal year, it's about $1.75 million, which means some of the contracts overlap the beginning and the end of the year.
Out of that
1 and 3 quarter million, about 10% of state funds or university funds from the engineering experiment station.
The rest is sponsored research from other agencies.
All of that, about a rough guess, 60% to 65% would be from federal agencies, the remainder from Texas industry.
What are some of the federal agencies that have research ?
Oh, NASA.
Air Force, Department of Energy, National Science Foundation, Veterans Administration.
I don't think we have anything for the Navy right now.
Did I mention the Air Force Army?
Currently, we don't.
I said Department of Energy.
Of course, Department of Energy takes care of a lot of different areas.
We did have some contracts, which I'm not sure have terminated or are still in effect from the nuclear side, Los Alamos Laboratories.
That's the primary agencies.
Another one doesn't come to mind right now.
This National Science Foundation has been criticized by some members of Congress
financial research that's of an alleged wasteful nature.
Do you have any comment on this?
Well, not in engineering.
I have some criticism for National Science Foundation.
But I personally have seen no research National Science Foundation has sponsored in engineering that I have been associated with that I would consider wasteful.
Only in the extent, first let me say what I believe an engineer is.
And let me say what I believe the difference between an engineer and a scientist, what the differences are.
I think it has nothing to do with intellectual capacity, but it has a difference to do with the objective that the various professions have.
I'd like to characterize it.
A scientist, whether he's a physicist or a chemist, typically

takes the role and is educated to such an extent that he is educated as an investigator, which we often use the word investigator, and his search usually is for a truth that's known but not known to him.
It's a fact in nature that is hidden and so he's
He's essentially searching for truth and knowledge that's existing, but not necessarily uncovered.
An engineer, on the other hand, I think, as I often say, has, if you may have noticed outside, it says mechanical engineering is a creative profession.
I feel an engineer has to have the ability to use the tools of a scientist.
He has to have the same skills of a...
use the same mathematical tools as a physicist.
He has to have the same ability to use a computer as a mathematician.
He has to be conversant with the same chemistry as a chemical engineer does with a chemist.
But he has to have one more ingredient, certainly in mechanical engineering.
He has to have the creative ability of an artist.
He has to have a mixture of both.
Because he's not called upon just to search for truth.
but to typically leave a product, to innovate something that came out of his vision of his mind to solve a problem.
And so if you think about an engineer, and I don't mean necessarily just a degree, many good physicists or educated in physics are very good engineers.
But if you can talk about the difference in attitude, an engineer must have a strong visual capability.
to be able to see products that don't exist in nature but that he is creating.
And so the attitude between a scientist and an engineer has to be somewhat different.
The same individual could obviously be either.
The National Science Foundation has been completely dominated by scientists.
There are
essentially no engineers in the National Science Foundation.
Now, very recently there are a few, primarily because of a large movement in engineering to create a National Engineering Foundation.
And so there has been a movement by the National Science Foundation to say, yes, we have engineers too.
In fact, the brand new director is an engineer.
But because the influence from scientists
was such that scientific research, understanding the difference, was funded as basic research and not basic engineering research.
There are certain areas that this country is in serious problem, have a serious problem.
And I think if anyone has read the papers about our productivity compared to the Japanese and Europeans, there is some cause for concern.
And if one looks at where we have serious problems in this country, we find that we really haven't done any research improving productivity.
We really haven't developed better machines.
We're not competitive in machine tools, and light equipment, and light appliances, and automobiles even.
We are competitive in electronics today.
are competitive internationally in science in a few areas.

So I blame the National Science Foundation for some of this, that the science, the funding that has gone to engineering schools from the government has been primarily from the National Science Foundation.
They've said, well, you must do fundamental research in fluid mechanics or material behavior.
But no one has been funding engineering development.
A criticism of the National Science Foundation is not waste, but of directing all of its funds toward science research and not engineering research.
And it's sort of come home to haunt us.
I think that's changing.
Hope.
Was there any other topic we need to touch on about runoff questions?
No.
You've got the history.
I do recommend you go talk to Charlie Crawford.
He was the department head before Dr. Simone.
He's still living and still alert?
He's in his 90s.
Right.
He wrote a history on this college.
The first 100 years of the College of Engineering.
And so I don't know what you're trying to accomplish in this project, whether it's a history of technology or technology in this school.
But he can probably give you a better perspective of the changes over the last 50 years than
Any other, well, obviously any other living person, both from the college and the department.
OK, I appreciate you taking the time to talk with me.
